metadata.name: Their Bodies All Feathers and Light
metadata.description:
Original poetry-prompted digital art. 


Upon Finding the Cat Has Killed Another Bird

They weigh so little I wonder  
how they were even there to be killed, how

they were even there. How slight,  
how hollow their bodies when I lift them

from the shade of the porch, where  
like sleight of hand she's pulled them

from the morning: blue, brown. A cardinal,  
once. A goldfinch. Once, a huddled puff

of feathers still breathing, that I cupped  
in my hands and carried out to the wild edge

of the yard where the forest waits, unsure  
what else I could do. I still wonder about it,

that a life should weigh so little. There are so  
many ways of being alive. And I'm ashamed

to say the bright ones make me sadder,  
when it happens, when I find them left out back

like the trinkets my son once dropped anywhere  
just to keep them near. Their bodies all feathers

and light, until they aren'tâ€”vessels  
for the suspension of disbelief, like ladies

sawn apart or levitated in a magic show,  
their audience caught in the longing

to know the illusion, to know  
a secret that forgives itself for being kept.
